titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The case in which the Court have hitherto been engaged was this day finished, and that of Fletcher and Peck was called— Mr: Martin, for Fletcher the Plaintiff in Error opened the cause— I am to answer him to-morrow— I was engaged at home very late in the Night.

2. I argued the cause of Fletcher and Peck, on the part of the latter, and occupied the whole day; from eleven O’Clock untill past four in the afternoon. I was under the usual embarrassments which I have always experienced in public speaking, and notwithstanding all the pains I have taken, not sufficiently clear in my arrangement and method. In point of effect I was apparently not successful, and in my exposition, dull and tedious almost beyond endurance— The Court did however hear me through— Mr: Harper follows me to-morrow— I pass’d the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s—where was Mr: Harrison— Walk’d home from the capitol-hill; partly with Dr: Mitchill and Mr: Thruston.

3. Mr: Harper argued the case of Fletcher and Peck, on the part of Mr: Peck— He was between two and three hours— Mr: Martin then began his argument in the close, and went partly through it— He is to finish to-morrow— The Court adjourned to meet at 11. O’Clock in the morning— I spent the Evening at home— Mr: Fry was below part of the time.

4. Going up to the Capitol I met Mr: Quincy, who was on his way to Georgetown to get a passage to Baltimore.— The Court met at the usual hour and sat untill twelve— Mr: Martin continued his argument untill that time— And then adjourned untill two. I went to the Capitol, and witness’d the inauguration of Mr: Madison, as President of the United States— The house was very much crowded and its appearance very magnificent— He made a very short Speech, in a tone of voice so low that he could not be heard, after which the official Oath was administered to him by the Chief Justice of the United States— The four other judges of the Supreme Court being present, and in their robes— After the Ceremony was over, I went with Mrs: Johnson, and Mr: and Mrs: Hellen to pay the visit of custom— The company was received at Mr: Madison’s house; he not having yet removed to the President’s house— Mr: Jefferson was among the visitors.— The Court had adjourned untill 2. O’Clock. I therefore returned to them at that hour— Mr: Martin closed the argument in the cause of Fletcher and Peck— After which the Court adjourned— I came home to dinner, and in the Evening went with Mr: Hellen and the Ladies to a Ball at Long’s in honour of the new President— The crowd was excessive—the heat oppressive, and the entertainment bad— Mr: Jefferson was there— About Midnight the Ball broke up—

5. I went to Church this morning with Eliza and Adelaide Johnson, and heard Mr: Addison— Returned home, and employed the remainder of the day in writing letters; and preparing an argument on the Question respecting Corporations. Mr: Delort and Mr: Texier, and Mr: de Cabre were below in the Evening, but I could not leave my business— I was engaged upon it, untill about 1. in the morning; but did not finish.

6. This morning while at breakfast I received a note from Mr: Madison the new President, requesting me as I should go up to the Capitol-Hill, to call upon him at his late residence, or at the President’s house; which I accordingly did— He there informed me that he proposed to nominate me to the Senate as Minister Plenipotentiary to Russia— Mr: Jefferson had sent Mr: Short there last Summer; but on his nominating him, the Senate had rejected the nomination— Mr: Madison said he had been informed the objection was not to the mission, but to the man— That the Emperor of Russia had so frequently and so strongly urged a wish for an interchange of Ministers with this Country, that he, Mr: Madison was very desirous of complying with that inclination— That the commercial relations between the two Countries was important, and that in this disposition of the Emperor, perhaps some valuable advantages might be obtained— He apologized for not having given me earlier notice of this proposition, from the extraordinary pressure of business, which the recent occurrences had thrown upon him; and observed that the nominations must be sent in within the course of half-an-hour. I thank’d him for the confidence, which was indicated by this proposal, and enquired what the particular objects of negotiation would be; and at what time I should be required or expected to go— He said that there would be no particular immediate subject of negotiation, unless it should appear that commercial arrangements of mutual benefit might be made— But that if a negotiation
negotiation for Peace should ensue, and the principles of maritime rights become objects of the Treaty, the interests of the United States might require their participation— That at least it might be necessary to guard against any possible combination of the two powers at War against us, and that the cultivation of the Emperor of Russia’s friendship might in this respect be very important— He said that copies of Mr: Short’s instructions would be furnished me, and such further instructions as might occur as necessary— That as to the time of my departure, it might be, as soon as my convenience would admit—probably not under a month and perhaps more— The Salary and allowances would be those usual to Ministers of the same rank— I enquired what length of time the mission would probably continue— He said that was indefinite, and might depend upon Events— Perhaps three or four years— I told him that upon the little consideration I was able to give the subject upon this sudden notice, I could see no sufficient reason for refusing the nomination; though from the circumstances, the confirmation by the Senate might be uncertain— He again apologized for the shortness of the time, and said that if upon further consideration I should perceive any insuperable obstacle to my acceptance, on the confirmation of the appointment, I might still reserve the right of finally declining. On these grounds I consented that the nomination should be made.— I called to visit Mrs: Cushing with Eliza and Adelaide Johnson, and afterwards pass’d the day in attendance upon the Court— The Report of the nominations was circulated round within an hour of the time when I went into Court— An important Cause of the Assignees of Robert Bird was partly argued— When I got home I found all the nominations known there also.— That of Mr: R. Smith, as Secretary of State was this day confirmed— I spent the Evening, and untill late at Night in preparing for an Argument on the question of Jurisdiction in the Courts of the United States, in cases to which Corporations are parties.

7. Attended the Court, and argued the question respecting Corporations— The ground which I was obliged to take appeared to the Court to be altogether untenable; and I shortened my argument from the manifest inefficacy of all that I said to produce conviction upon the minds of any of the judges— The Chief-Justice intimated to me that they had already made up their opinions, and that the Court being divided, probably no judgment would be given this term— In the case of Fletcher and Peck also, he mentioned to Mr: Cranch, and judge Livingston had done the same to me on Saturday Night at the Ball, the reluctance of the Court to decide the case at-all; as it appeared manifestly made up for the purpose of getting the Court’s judgment upon all the points— And although they have given some decisions in such cases, they appear not disposed to do so now— While I was in Court, in the course of the day I was a whisper circulating that the Senate had not concurr’d in the nomination to Russia; and resolv’d that it is not expedient to send a Minister there at this time. There was a small party of Ladies and Gentlemen this Evening at Mr: Hellen’s, who staid very late— Mr: Stackpole confirm’d the information I had received in the morning— The Heads of Departments appointed, besides Mr: Smith are Dr: Eustis as Secretary at War—and Paul Hamilton Secretary of the Treasury Navy.— Mr: Gallatin remains at the head of the Treasury.

8. I attended Court again this day— They made great progress in the docket, and I think will now get through in a few days more. Since I have finished my Arguments I find myself much more at leisure— Spent this Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: Sheldon was there— Mrs: Boyd quite unwell— I had a difficult walk home— Warm, sultry weather—dark—rain, and deep mire— Eliza and Adelaide Johnson are at Mr: Boyd’s— Adelaide was prevented from coming home.

9. Called this morning upon Mr: Smith the Secretary of State, with an application from Mr: Cushing, for the Office of Consul at the Havanna. He informed me that the Office was now fill’d; and the Consul, Mr: Anderson was there. I wrote letters to Boston; and also attended the Court, whose business draws to a close— Mr: and Mrs: Buchanan arrived here this Evening.

10. I employed part of the morning in packing up the books and papers which I have here, to be sent round to Boston by water— Wrote some letters, and attended the Court— An insurance Cause of some interest came on, with a question, as to the effect of an exception of blockaded places from the policy— The two youngest judges Johnson and Livingston appear easy to take a bias, and ready to manifest it— The Chief Justice informed Mr: Cranch that he would have delivered the opinion of the Court in the case of Fletcher and Peck; which would be a verbal opinion; if I had been in Court— And that he would deliver it to-morrow morning.

11. This morning the Chief Justice read a written opinion in the case of Fletcher and Peck— The judgment in the Circuit Court is reversed for a defect in the Pleadings— With regard to the merits of the case, the Chief Justice added verbally, that circumstanced as the Court are, only five judges attending, there were difficulties which would have prevented them from giving any opinion at this term, had the pleadings been correct— And the Court the more readily forbore giving it, as from the complection of the pleadings they could not but see, that at the time when the Covenants were made, the parties had notice of the acts covenanted against. That this was not to be taken as part of the Court’s opinion; but as a motive why they had thought proper not to give one at this term— I then enquired whether the Court had formed an opinion, upon the issue made up by the special verdict—to which he answered that on that and the right of the Legislature to sell, if the opinion of the Court had been against the defendant they would have given it— I dined with Mr: Cranch—who in the Evening brought me home in his chair.

12. Went to Church at Georgetown with Mr: Hellen, Mr: Buchanan, and Eliza and Adelaide Johnson— Heard Mr: Addison preach a Sermon upon the blessing of meekness.— Dined at Mr: Boyd’s, and spent the Evening there— Mr: Ross and Mr: Fry; Miss Roberts and Miss Howard came in there after dinner— I wrote to my wife, and to Mr: Peck, informing him of the issue of his Cause.

13. Called at the Stage-Office in Georgetown, and engaged my passage for Baltimore the day after to-morrow— Also at the Branch Bank in the City— Attended Court, and endeavoured to provide a remedy for the defects in the Pleadings in the case of Fletcher & Peck. To meet the objections against them, there must be an entire repleader— I drew an Agreement which was signed by Mr: Martin and myself, that all exceptions to the pleadings shall be waved, and the case submitted to the Court upon the Covenants, and the facts appearing upon the record— If the Court will consent to this agreement, the judgment of reversal will not be entered, but the case will be continued untill the next term for further argument upon the merits.— I took a copy of the written opinion of the Court delivered on Saturday. They will not give this term an opinion upon the Corporation question— We had a snow-storm which continued the whole of this day— I brought home my books from the Capitol-Hill, and pack’d up most of my goods, for my departure.

14. At the War-Office, and mentioned the applications of Coll: Hatch, and Mr: Charles Harrod for Commissions— The Secretary of State and Mr: Granger were neither of them at their Offices— I called also at the President’s; but as Mr: Erskine was going in at the same time, I merely left a card— Attended Court— The Court had consented to the agreement in the case of Fletcher and Peck, which I had yesterday drawn up; but the Chief-Justice had lost the paper from his Pocket; and I was obliged to draw another, which I signed, and left to be signed by Mr: Martin— Mr: Cranch engaged that it should be filed— I urged the Court for a decision upon the question relating to Corporations; but the Court said it could not be decided this term. Judge Livingston however told me that judge Washington had said he would again urge the Chief-Justice to decide it; at least on the question of the averment— I cannot however wait for it— It was between 4 and 5. O’Clock when the Court adjourned and I came home— They will probably not sit longer than to-morrow— I have during this term made many observations, on the present composition of the Court, and the practice in it, which would be useful to me, if I had time to note them down while they are fresh upon my mind; but which will soon slip from my recollection, and turn to no account— I have severely felt my own defects, and the want of experience in business— Yet I have seen that the practice is not unattainable; if the opportunities were afforded me, and my eyes were sound.— Mr: Buchanan went to Bladensburg, on his way home; leaving his wife here— In the Evening I wrote something, and prepared to take my departure for home to-morrow morning.

15. The hour fixed for the departure of the Stage this morning was five O’Clock— But it was almost six when they called for me. There were already several passengers in the carriage, and they stop’d to take in several others, after I took my seat— It was past 7. before we started finally from Stelle’s Hotel— The excessive badness of the common road made them go round over the Eastern Branch of the Potowmack to Bladensburg— I found Mr: Buchanan there— We breakfasted at Ross’s— Dined at Spurrier’s; and Arrived a little before 10 at Night at Gadsby’s Tavern in Baltimore— I have never known the roads so bad— At Breakfast and at dinner, we met Mr: Latrobe, who was in the Mail-Stage, with which we travell’d the whole day in Company— Latrobe has so much conversation, and so much wit, that I regretted I had not the good luck to be in the same Stage with him— The Company in ours was as dull, as the road was irksome.

16. At 9 this Morning, I took passage in the Packet President Captain Ferguson, in the New-Line of the Water-Stages to Philadelphia. Met Mr: Buchanan in the Street— He came yesterday on horse-back from Bladensburg— He came down with me to the Packet and there took leave of me— We sailed with a very light wind, which soon became a calm, and so continued with occasional very light breezes the whole day and Night— The Company was worse than indifferent, and for the sake of avoiding incumbrance of baggage, I had taken no books with me— The time hung very heavy upon me— Among the passengers were two women from Georgetown; one of them with a child about a year old, and without any man in their company— They were of very decent in appearance and manners, but without any pretensions of refinement— There were seven men of whom two had the air and deportment of sharpers, and two of cullies— One of the former had brought on board a pack of cards, and was applying to every body to play with him— They soon formed a party of four, and played all-fours; the two sharpers as partners, against the two dupes— Playing first for glasses of gin-toddy, bottles of cider, and eleven penny bits. Which they continued untill dinner time— After dinner the sport was renewed untill Supper— And the moment the cloth was removed the cards were again resumed— About 11. at Night I went to bed—leaving them playing for six eleven penny-bits the remainder of Mr: Bines’s small-change. After sleeping untill about five in the Morning I awoke and found them playing for ten dollars a game— January—(the name by which the keenest and most polished of the two cunning ones pass’d) marking down 25 dollars, as what Bines then owed him, and calling every five minutes for a glass of gin-toddy, of which he drank nothing himself, but which Bines continued to swallow—swearing at his luck—quarreling with January; who alternately rallied and bullied him, untill he had strip’d him of all his money, and got him fifty-five dollars in his debt— About 7. O’Clock, the boy came and broke up their game, by calling for the table to lay the Cloth for Breakfast.— In coming down the river from Baltimore, we saw a number of light vessels loading for sea, and several ready to sail— This being the day, on which the Embargo ceases throughout the United States— There was great stir and appearance of active business on the river, and at the wharves.

17. About 8. this morning we landed at Cecil-point, and immediately took Stages for Newcastle. I went with the two women, and two others of the passengers, leaving the four gamblers together in the other Stage— The roads were very bad, though not so heavy or dangerous as from Baltimore to Washington— About 2. in the afternoon we arrived at Newcastle and immediately came on board the Packet George Washington, Captain Robertson— The wind was then fair and fresh, but within half an hour died away, and a flat calm ensued— About 5 in the afternoon the tide turned against us, and we came to anchor untill 11. at Night— About that time one of the female passengers who had gone to bed in the back cabin— Came forward complaining of having been intruded upon by a man who in the dark had groped to her birth, and thrust his hand into her bed— She took back a candle with her on returning to bed, and kept it burning the whole Night.

18. At 5 in the morning, the tide having turned against us, and the total calm still continuing, we were again obliged to come to anchor. After all the passengers had risen there was a sort of Scrutiny to fix upon the amorous adventurer of last Night— The strongest suspicions fell upon Bines, the unlucky gamester of the day before— At least he defended himself most feebly against the charge— There were however circumstances which bore hard upon his associate January— But he denied the fact with such direct and solemn asseveration, at the same time bantering his friend Bines with so much assurance that he escaped at least from the general belief that he was the offender— About 10. in the morning they both landed together in the packet’s boat, and returned to Philadelphia by land— We continued anchored opposite the Lazaretto untill 11. O’Clock, and then again drifted with the tide, untill 4. in the afternoon, when we reached the wharf at Philadelphia— I took my lodgings at the mansion-house hotel; and immediately called at the house of the Chevalier de Foronda the Spanish Consul-General; to make enquiries of him, for information upon business of Mr: W. Gray of Salem— I found nearly a dozen persons, apparently merchants, at the door, clamouring for admission; and a servant telling them that his master would not see them, and they must call again. They were bitterly complaining that they had already called three or four times and been put off from one hour to another, and always turned off again at the appointed times— I told the servant that I wished to see his Master upon other business, but he said he would not be seen by any body then; and would see me about the dusk of the Evening— I called on Mr: Ewing at his Office, and sat with him untill about dusk— Then went again to the house of the Chevalier de Foronda
and was again refused admission to him, and told to come at 10 O’Clock to-morrow morning, when he would see me— I then went and pass’d a couple of hours at Dr: Rush’s— On returning to my lodgings I found judge Livingston there— He left Washington on Thursday morning— Baltimore yesterday in the same line of Packets by which I came, and arrived here within two hours after I did— So that I might have remained another day in Washington, without losing one here— The judge informed me that notwithstanding the refusal of the Court the day before I came away to decide the question respecting Corporations, as I requested, they did decide it the next day; against us; but in favour of the general Jurisdiction of the Courts of the United States, in cases to which Corporations are parties:— The Court finished their Session the day I left Washington.

19. Judge Livingston proceeded upon his journey to New-York. I called at the hour of appointment on the Chevalier de Foronda, and was told by his Servant that he could not see me to day, but requested I would call again to-morrow— I sent him word that I should not trouble him again. I dined with Mr: Ewing at his lodgings— After dinner Mr: R. M’Call, and Mr: Meredith came in— I received from Mr: A. M’Call a card inviting me to come to his house, and went— I found a large company with him at dinner— Sat with them about an hour— Then visited again Dr: Rush—afterwards called at Mr: Hopkinson’s, and spent the remainder of the Evening at Mr: Meredith’s, with Hopkinson, Ewing and Dr: Earle— It was midnight before I returned to my lodgings.

20. At 8 O’Clock this morning I took a seat in the Diligence Stage, for New-York— On getting into the Carriage I found Mr: John Montgomery the member of Congress from Maryland there— We afterwards took in a Sea-Captain, who lives near Princeton, and three Spaniards lately arrived from Spain— The Stage was to have travell’d this day as far as Brunswick; but the roads were so bad, that we could not get further than Princeton where we arrived about 8 in the Evening. We dined at Trenton— The bridge at the Shammony river had been carried away, and we were obliged to cross it in a small canoe; and hire an open waggon in which we rode the remainder of that Stage; three miles to Bristol— Our Sea-Captain left us at his residence about 6 miles short of Princeton— We met also a common Sailor, walking to New-York, who joined convoy with us for a few miles— Mr: Montgomery held much conversation with him in his dialect, with which Montgomery appeared perfectly familiar.

21. We took the Stage between four and five this Morning, and cross’d the brook at Kingston, which last Evening was impassable. We breakfasted at Brunswick, and dined at Gifford’s in Newark— I called to see Mrs: Smith, the Coll:’s mother; and there saw also Mrs: Clarkson and Nancy— Afterwards stop’d there in the Stage, and took a trunk and letter for Mrs: Charles Adams at Quincy— We reached Paulus-Hoek, just before dark, and cross’d the river as the Evening closed in— Passing by the Stage, and Rhode-island Packet Office in Cortlandt Street, I stop’d and enquired if there was any packet ready to sail, and was told that the Juno, Captain Comstock would sail for Providence to-morrow morning at 10. Mr: Montgomery and myself took our lodgings at the City Hotel— I went and pass’d the Evening with Mr: King— While I was there, Mr: Wolcott and Mr: Henderson came in, for an hour or two. On returning to my lodgings I found Coll: Troup, a member of Congress from Georgia, and Dr: Kirkpatrick late a member from the State of New-York, with Mr: Montgomery— We all supp’d together and sat in conversation until past Midnight.

22. Immediately after breakfast this morning I went down to Crane-wharf, and found the Packet Juno, near the point of departing. I went on board, and there saw Coll: Howard of Kentuckey, who with Mr: Johnson, both members of Congress from that State, are going in this Packet— The Captain was not on board, and I could not see him. I desired one of his men to ask him, if he should be ready to go, to wait untill I could come with my baggage from the City-Hotel— I immediately went there, and returned with my baggage to the wharf, but found the Packet gone, about 5 minutes— It was as much too late as if it had been five hours— I had only to take my disappointment with Patience, and to put my baggage on board the Packet Golden Age Captain Perry, who intends sailing for Newport to-morrow— I sat and wrote there, a couple of hours— Called at Mr: M’Cormick’s, but he was abroad. Returned to the City-Hotel, and lounged— Called again on Mr: M’Cormick, whom I found— He went with me to Mr: Wilkins’s Office where I found my nephew John A. Smith— Mr: King last Evening had invited me to dine with him to-day. I had told him I should in all probability go away this morning, but he had desired me, if I should not, to come without ceremony
and dine with him— I went accordingly but found he was gone to pass the day at his seat on Long-Island— I returned and dined at my lodgings at the City Hotel— In the Evening, finding that I had nothing to do, I went to the Play and saw the forty thieves, with the farce of Animal Magnetism— Mr: Verplanck junr: called in at the Box where I was seated, for part of the Evening.

23. It blew a gale of wind from the North and East which prevented the packet from sailing this day— I went down to it immediately after breakfast, to enquire whether it was going; and while on the wharf received a note from Mr: Pendleton, requesting to see me, and to take some depositions at Boston immediately after my return— I called upon Mr: Pendleton consequently and had some conversation with him upon the subject.— Judge Benson also called upon me at the City Hotel, respecting some other business of Insurance and law; and I had conversation with him upon it— I returned to the Packet, and wrote there two or three hours— A gentleman came on board to engage a passage for himself and his Sister in law, for whom I resigned my State-room— I dined with Mr: M’Cormick where I met again this gentleman whom I found to be a Mr: Henry—his Sister is a Mrs: Hill a daughter of the late Mrs: Duché of Philadelphia. Mr: Robertson—Mr: Bell—a nephew of Mr: M’Cormick’s, bearing his name, and my nephew J. A. Smith dined with us— The Evening, I pass’d at my lodgings— Mr: John Coles came into Mr: M’Cormick’s after dinner.

24. At nine this morning I came on board the Packet Golden Age, Captain Perry, of Newport, the wind and weather being both perfectly fair— It was eleven however before we left the wharf—several of the Passengers having delayed untill that time coming on board— Mr: Henry and Mrs: Hill— Mr: Whittemore of Boston and his daughter, Mr: Ezra Davis, and several other gentlemen are fellow passengers with us— Our wind continued fair the whole day and Evening; blowing very fresh the whole time— Towards Evening the weather assumed a threatening appearance, and it snow’d for about an hour— But as the moon rose it cleared away and the Night was fine—before midnight we were opposite to New-London, at the distance of one hundred and fifty miles from New-York.

25. At 5. O’Clock this morning our Packet grounded within a few paces of the wharf at Newport. Having been precisely eighteen hours from New-York; which is the shortest passage through the sound that I ever made— But as usual, on arriving at Newport we had the wind against us for going up to Providence; and there was no Packet going for several hours— Mr: Ezra Davis, another passenger (an Englishman) and myself therefore took an extra Stage to Boston— The regular Stage having been gone about half an hour when we arrived— It was however eight O’Clock before we could have the Stage in readiness, and at that time we left Newport— The roads were very bad, and just before we reached the new Bridge at Tiverton, twelve miles from Newport, one of the Springs of our Carriage broke— We had then about 7 miles more to Freetown the end of our first Stage. Our only resource was to procure a Cart, to carry our baggage, tackling into it two of our horses; while two of us rode the other two horses, and I walk’d the whole distance except about a mile, which I rode with the baggage in the Cart— Arriving at Freetown about 2. O’Clock P.M. we found that Mr: Davis’s trunk had been lost from the cart; and sent the driver back after it— This detained us more than two hours longer— At length however the trunk was found and brought up to us, and between 4 and 5. in the afternoon we left Freetown 18. miles from Newport— The next Stage was to Taunton 17. miles, which notwithstanding the excessive roughness of the roads we reached about 7. in the Evening. Having a fine moon-light we determined to go another Stage of 17 miles, and arrived at Sharon, between 10 and 11. at Night— One of our horses however gave out about 2 miles before we reached the end of this Stage, and our driver was obliged to exchange him for another— We stop for a short Night at Sharon— I was somewhat fatigued— But one of my fellow-travellers, who backed the horses, was ill, almost to fainting— Both complained much.

26. Soon after day-break this morning we resumed our Seats in the Stage, and travelling over the blue-hills came into the old Milton road, South of the Bridge, and into Boston, where I landed at my own house about nine in the morning— I had the happiness to find my wife and children well; excepting Charles who has a troublesome eruption upon the face— George is at Mr: Cranch’s at Quincy and attending school at Mr: Whitney’s— In the afternoon I went with Catherine Johnson, and heard Mr: Emerson— Called in the Evening at Judge Davis’s, and requested him to issue Subpoena’s to Messrs: Lloyd and Preble, Head and Amory, to take their depositions in the case with which I was charged by Mr: Pendleton— He said he would, and desired me to call upon him to-morrow-Morning, on this business.

27. I called this morning upon Judge Davis, who gave me a summons for the four gentlemen whose depositions are wanted for Mr: Church to appear and depose before him on Thursday the 30th: instt: at 10. O’Clock in the Morning; two days notice being considered as sufficient— He also gave me a citation of notice to Thomas Amory and R. G. Amory his attorney to be present at the taking of the depositions— I sent the Summons to the Marshal to be served, and gave the notice to Mr: R. G. Amory myself, which notice he acknowledged on the back of the citation— I called for a few minutes at my Office; and saw Mr: Peck, and Messrs: Boardman and Pope— Was also at the fire and Marine Insurance Office— Mr: Ripley dined with us— Mr: Dyer called to see me this afternoon, and informed me of the difficulties which have arisen to obstruct the progress of our projected Market plan— Mr: Emerson paid us a visit this Evening.

28. My brother came into town this morning, and dined with us— He also returned here this Evening, and lodges with us— He has some business at the Supreme Court now sitting in this town, and fares much as I have done at Washington— I attended the Court a short time in the morning— In the Evening attended a meeting of the Directors of the Boylston Market Association; one of whom I have been chosen during my absence; and also their President— We had the meeting at Mr: Knapp’s— The difficulties respecting the conveyance of the land were discuss’d but not removed— We adjourned to meet this day week.

29. My brother left us this morning before Breakfast— I attended the Supreme Court, part of the day; and heard Mr: Hall and Mr: Dexter, argue the question, against the conclusiveness of the Sentence of a foreign Court of Admiralty, as to the facts asserted in it. Club this Evening at Mr: Emerson’s— Mr: Tyng has left them— And a proposition was made for the admission of judge Parker. Mr: Cushing called upon me this afternoon to learn the State of his Cause— I had nothing agreeable to tell him—

30. The Night was excessively cold— And my thermometer when I rose this morning, between 7 and 8 O’Clock stood at 15— At 10. according to appointment I attended before Judge Davis at W. S. Shaw’s Office, to take the Depositions— Mr: Lloyd was there; but the judge not immediately coming, soon became impatient and went away.— The other Gentlemen attended— I gave each of them a copy of the questions directed by Mr: Pendleton to be put— They wished time for recollection, and the judge adjourned the meeting untill 5 1/2 P.M.— We all attended again at that hour; and the judge took the depositions of Messrs: Jonn: Amory, Preble and Lloyd— Adjourned to 5 to-morrow afternoon to take that of Mr: Head.

div.p: 31. I sent this Morning to judge Davis for the depositions yesterday taken, and wrote to Mr: Pendleton; but before I could get the packet to the Post-Office, the mail for this day was closed— About Noon I walk’d to Cambridge— Found the road not very bad— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Attended the Declamation at 2. and read my tenth Lecture at 3. In the interval between the two exercises I called upon President Webber, to whom I had written the day before yesterday giving him notice of my return— I found the Corporation upon receiving the copies of my letters which I had left for them had concluded not to do any thing further in regard to the subject of my absence; and had found no difficulty in supplying my place. After reading my lecture I returned to Boston— Judge Davis at 5 O’Clock came, and took the deposition of Mr: Head— Mr: R. G. Amory attended as Counsel for his brother— We were engaged untill past 9 in the Evening in taking the deposition— Judge Davis took it home with him, to draw the caption and certificate; to have in readiness to-morrow morning— But after I came home, Mr: Head came and told me that he wished to give some additional testimony to-morrow morning, to explain part of his deposition this Evening— I agreed therefore to meet him at the judge’s house at 9 1/2 to-morrow morning.

Day— The first half of the month like that which preceded it— The next ten days, traveling from Washington— The last week quite unsettled— It would be my wish, and if I could make resolutions, would be my determination, to fix upon some one object of application to which I should devote all my leisure time— But I fear nothing less than a necessity of external causes can overcome the indolence of my nature, and the instinctive horror of long and systematic pursuit of one purpose— This is one of the most essential defects in my character.
